Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC Center for Atomically Thin Multifunctional Coatings (ATOMIC)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research of the planned I/UCRC for Atomically Thin Multifunctional Coatings aims to focus on fundamental understanding of synthesis, integration, properties, processing and scale-up of novel 2D material systems of application importance. The proposed Industry-University partnership plans to build on a foundation of scientific innovation in 2D materials at Penn State and Rice University in such materials as graphene, MoS2, WS2, hBN, and WSxSe1-x. The planned research activities of the center are student-centric, and will include: performing transformational and applied research, developing intellectual property, low cost nano-manufacturing, doing internships at the industry, and undertaking technology transfer.

The planned I/UCRC will closely coordinate joint activities to involve underrepresented students at all levels of education; for example, through the new Penn State - Millennium Scholars Program, supporting research summer stays at both universities. Undergraduate students will be provided opportunities to take part in ongoing interdisciplinary research in the center. In order to encourage young people to pursue science-technology research, the center will jointly conduct activities such as the Upward Bound Math and Science (UBMS) and leverage ongoing PSU/Rice MRSEC REU and RET programs. The center also intends to generate strategies to remediate current technology drawbacks and spur local and regional economic growth through Penn State's Innovation Park and The Rice Alliance for Technology and Entrepreneurship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

1362072: Planning Grant: I/UCRC Center for Atomically Thin Multifunctional Coatings (ATOMIC)

This project seeks to establish a multidisciplinary and internationally leading center devoted to the design and development of advanced coatings based on two-dimensional (2D) layered materials (Center for Atomically Thin Multifunctional Coatings -ATOMIC). This center will integrate students, faculty, and staff from The Pennsylvania State University and Rice University, and leading National and International Industries. The joint research efforts will concentrate on defining societal and industrial needs regarding advanced coatings with applications in key strategic areas in the national interest of US: corrosion, oxidation and abrasion resistance, friction and wear, multifunctional sensors and actuators, anti-bacterial, anti-fouling, and catalysis. The first stage for the successful creation of the center and the key objective of this planning grant is an interactive planning session between academia and industry to establish the most critical opportunities in coating technologies and define transformational objectives that will result in new US-based technologies.

The Penn State and Rice PIs organized the ATOMIC planning meeting at the Penn Stater hotel at PSU. The meeting was held on 21-22 of October, 2014. The NSF program director Dr. Shashank Prya and Dr. Steve McGregor (NSF evaluator) attended the meeting. During the ATOMIC planning meeting and through a close interaction of committed industry members and faculty experts in 2D materials, we have identified five initial technology topics for ATOMIC to establish the foundation of the Center. This IUCRC ATOMIC Center will initially be addressing problems in the areas of: 1) Scalable Routes for ATOMIC, 2) Synthesis and Characterization of Atomically Thin Materials Applied in Energy Conversion and Storage, 3) Atomic Layers for Anti-Corrosion Coatings, and 4) Tough and Transparent Multi-Functional Films, and 5) Reliability and Multi-functionality of the ATOMIC materials developed in the top four projects.

We have successfully achieved the main goals of this planning grant as follows:

1. Together with Industry, we identified and prioritized key thrust areas that were strategic for the industry attending the planning meeting;

2. We planned and projected a long term sustainable vision for ATOMIC that was part of the ATOMIC full proposal;

3. We proposed and polished the management plan with possible Industrial members and obtained drafts of memorandum of agreement, policies, and operation of ATOMIC. These were also included in the final proposal.

Additionally, We have disseminated the information learned and compiled from the planning grant via a dedicated webpage, pamphlets, and also a topics booklet we designed for attracting possible industrial partners. We also coordinated the elaboration of power point presentations that were presented during the planning grant meeting.
